text.p: Suppose [mathjaxinline]V[/mathjaxinline] and [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] are vector spaces with the same (finite) dimension [mathjaxinline]n[/mathjaxinline].
If [mathjaxinline]T: V\rightarrow W[/mathjaxinline] is a linear transformation which is into, what is the nullity of [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline]?
Therefore, what is the rank of [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline]?
Therefore, we can conclude that [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] must be what? (Answer yourself.)

font.p: Since [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is into, the kernel of [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is [mathjaxinline]\{ \mathbf{0}\}[/mathjaxinline]. Therefore, the dimension of the kernel of [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline], and the nullity of [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline], is 0. Since the dimension of the domain is [mathjaxinline]n[/mathjaxinline], by the rank nullity theorem, the rank of [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is [mathjaxinline]n-0=n[/mathjaxinline].

This means that the image of [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] is a subspace of [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] with dimension [mathjaxinline]n[/mathjaxinline]. But since [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline] also has dimension [mathjaxinline]n[/mathjaxinline], this means that the image of [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] equals [mathjaxinline]W[/mathjaxinline]. In other words, [mathjaxinline]T[/mathjaxinline] must be onto.
